an6.56:1.1: Now at that time Venerable Phagguṇa was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
an6.56:1.2: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
an6.56:1.4: Sir, please go to Venerable Phagguṇa out of compassion.”
an6.56:1.6: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Venerable Phagguṇa.
an6.56:1.7: Venerable Phagguṇa saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
an6.56:1.8: and tried to rise on his cot.
an6.56:1.10: “It’s all right, Phagguṇa, don’t get up.
an6.56:1.11: There are some seats spread out by others, I will sit there.”
an6.56:1.12: He sat on the seat spread out
an6.56:2.1: “I hope you’re keeping well, Phagguṇa; I hope you’re alright. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
an6.56:2.2: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.
an6.56:3.1: The winds piercing my head are so severe, it feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point.
an6.56:4.1: The pain in my head is so severe, it feels like a strong man tightening a tough leather strap around my head.
an6.56:5.1: The winds piercing my belly are so severe, it feels like a deft butcher or their apprentice is slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver.
an6.56:6.1: The burning in my body is so severe, it feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.
an6.56:6.2: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”
an6.56:6.3: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Venerable Phagguṇa with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.
an6.56:7.1: Not long after the Buddha left, Venerable Phagguṇa passed away.
an6.56:7.2: At the time of his death, his faculties were bright and clear.
an6.56:7.3: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
an6.56:7.4: “Sir, soon after the Buddha left, Venerable Phagguṇa died.
an6.56:7.5: At the time of his death, his faculties were bright and clear.”
an6.56:8.1: “And why shouldn’t his faculties be bright and clear?
an6.56:8.2: The mendicant Phagguṇa’s mind was not freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:8.3: But when he heard that teaching his mind was freed from them.
an6.56:9.1: Ānanda, there are these six benefits to hearing the teaching at the right time and examining the meaning at the right time.
an6.56:9.3: Firstly, take the case of a mendicant whose mind is not freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:9.4: At the time of death they get to see the Realized One.
an6.56:9.5: The Realized One teaches them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
an6.56:9.6: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:9.7: This is the first benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:10.1: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is not freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:10.2: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, but they get to see a Realized One’s disciple.
an6.56:10.3: The Realized One’s disciple teaches them Dhamma …
an6.56:10.4: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:10.5: This is the second benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:11.1: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is not freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:11.2: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, or to see a Realized One’s disciple.
an6.56:11.3: But they think about and consider the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.
an6.56:11.4: As they do so their mind is freed from the five lower fetters.
an6.56:11.5: This is the third benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:12.1: Next, take the case of a mendicant whose mind is freed from the five lower fetters, but not with the supreme ending of attachments.
an6.56:12.2: At the time of death they get to see the Realized One.
an6.56:12.3: The Realized One teaches them Dhamma …
an6.56:12.4: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed with the supreme ending of attachments.
an6.56:12.5: This is the fourth benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:13.1: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is freed from the five lower fetters, but not with the supreme ending of attachments.
an6.56:13.2: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, but they get to see a Realized One’s disciple.
an6.56:13.3: The Realized One’s disciple teaches them Dhamma …
an6.56:13.4: When they hear that teaching their mind is freed with the supreme ending of attachments.
an6.56:13.5: This is the fifth benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:14.1: Next, take the case of another mendicant whose mind is freed from the five lower fetters, but not with the supreme ending of attachments.
an6.56:14.2: At the time of death they don’t get to see the Realized One, or to see a Realized One’s disciple.
an6.56:14.3: But they think about and consider the teaching in their heart, examining it with the mind as they learned and memorized it.
an6.56:14.4: As they do so their mind is freed with the supreme ending of attachments.
an6.56:14.5: This is the sixth benefit of listening to the teaching.
an6.56:15.1: These are the six benefits to hearing the teaching at the right time and examining the meaning at the right time.”
